Leaving the car at home and using public transport looked futile last night as bus companies stopped night services, diesel trains were cancelled, London Underground drivers struggled to get to work and taxis in the north began to charge double rates.

Stagecoach spokesman Barry Gardner said 75% of buses nationwide had enough fuel to run normal services until Friday. After that, less popular routes outside 8am to 6pm would have to be cancelled.

The worst hit were buses in the north-west and Wales. The Stagecoach bus depot in Chadderton, greater Manchester, yesterday ran out of fuel as did three other bus depots in Bolton, Wigan, and Glossop, Derbyshire. Bullocks bus company suspended all services in Cheshire and south Manchester between 10am and 3pm, while callers to BBC Greater Manchester Radio complained that taxis in the area were charging double rates.

In Gwent, Wales, around 50% of Stagecoach buses were cancelled and 30% of services stopped in Cheltenham and Gloucester.

From tomorrow, rural areas in Cumbria and Suffolk could become cut off outside rush hour.

Electric trams in Blackpool and Manchester were taking extra passengers and in Merseyside electric trains were preparing to run extra services.

But two-thirds of the national train network runs on diesel fuel and the Association of Train Operating Companies said yesterday that companies only had enough to last until Friday.

South West Trains began cancelling services yesterday, terminating its London Waterloo to Paignton, south Devon, service around 30 miles short at Exeter. This was likely to be repeated today.

The Brighton to Reading service was being terminated at Basingstoke.

Railtrack had to call in extra staff to control crowds at peak hour times, and some train companies reported a 50% increase in passengers.

Railtrack has brought in extra beds at key locations so that staff can sleep between shifts. Diesel fuel supplies a considerable part of the rural network so train operating companies in these areas will be the first to suffer when supplies dry up.

Meanwhile, the British Airports Authority yesterday advised airlines to refuel at Heathrow or Gatwick airports, which have so far been unaffected because they have private pipelines for fuel. East Midlands, Luton and Liverpool airports asked airlines such as Easy Jet to refuel abroad and enter Britain with enough for a round trip.
Angelique Chrisafis and Keith Harper

Health service

The Department of Health warned last night that the fuel blockade was putting the NHS under "massive pressure" as people who could not get home visits by GPs and district nurses turned up at hospitals' accident and emergency departments. Many ambulance crews were answering emergency calls only.

A spokesman blamed the crisis for the cancellation of dozens of operations yesterday. "There is no doubt that the longer the blockades continue, the more chance there is of lives being put at risk," he said.

"GPs and district nurses are not able to visit elderly and vulnerable people in their own homes. Ambulances have cancelled non-emergency journeys and NHS staff are having great problems getting to work in many areas.

"This means that operations are now being cancelled and A&E departments are coming under more pressure as people cannot call out doctors easily."

The department said NHS blood stocks were reasonably high, but fuel shortages were hindering the collection of newly donated blood in some parts of the country. "Blood supplies are being moved around the country causing delays to deliveries. Vital hospital supplies - including medicines - are beginning to run low in some places," the spokesman said.

NHS managers were working to find emergency fuel supplies and pool meagre resources. Emergency planning teams, normally only used to ease pressures in the health service during the winter, were being set up to deal with the crisis.

Some local health authorities were issuing doctors, nurses and other health workers with special certificates to allow them to access emergency fuel supplies.

Protesters yesterday allowed fuel supplies earmarked for local ambulance services through the noose round refineries at Stanlow in Cheshire and Grangemouth, near Edinburgh, as well as distribution depots in Ipswich and Leeds.

Motorway garages also introduced a guaranteed supply system for emergency services, including all 42 sites run by Granada. London's big hospitals also held a joint meeting to draw up emergency plans to pool fuel for back-up generators if the crisis deepened, while routine operations were cancelled in mid-Wales and Staffordshire ambulances imposed a 55mph limit on non-urgent callouts.
John Carvel and Martin Wainwright

Supermarkets and shops

Some shops and supermarkets have seen customers clearing the shelves of bread, milk, flour and sugar as panic buying has shifted from petrol to groceries.

Although supermarkets assured customers they had enough fuel for food deliveries for the foreseeable future, this actually meant up to the weekend, according to the British Retail Consortium.

Drivers at the frozen food company Iceland claimed they would not be able to make food deliveries after tomorrow.

Tim Mason, marketing director at Tesco, said yesterday that ultimately fresh food supplies would be affected by the fuel crisis. However, a company spokeswoman said there had been no evidence of panic buying.

Staff at shops and supermarkets in the West Country have witnessed panic buying of fresh and dried milk, bread and flour. Pat Bint, acting manageress of Londis in South Cerney, near Cirencester, sold out of bread and milk within 90 minutes of the shop opening yesterday.

Sales at Somerfield's supermarket at Malmesbury, Wiltshire, had increased by 7% over the last four days. Shelves were being cleared of bread, milk, eggs and sugar, according to store manager Stuart Yeandel.

Roy Litchfield, treasurer of the National Association of Shopkeepers, warned that commerce could grind to a halt because of the shortage of fuel. He said the impact could be felt by shopkeepers within the next five to seven days. "It is really going to start to bite in the next few days. How are they supposed to get food to people if there is no petrol and there are no buses to transport people into towns and cities?"
Helen Carter

Business

The Confederation of British Industry yesterday warned that the country's hard-pressed manufacturing sector would start shutting down production lines today because of the fuel crisis.

The motor industry, food processing and steel manufacturing were running out of raw materials, had fuel shortages or had nowhere to store the goods which could not be delivered.

Service industries were finding difficulty getting out to see clients and workers in rural areas without public transport could not get to work.

A CBI spokesperson said: "It does look serious but some sectors are worse hit than others."

Transport companies saw their shares take a battering on the stock market as companies such as P&O, Hays and Excel were marked down by City pessimists.

A spokesman for P&O, which delivers containers and other goods from Tilbury and Southampton docks, said the crisis "is beginning to impede the flow of goods around the country."

Virgin said its megastores could run out of CDs and mobile phones within two weeks if they could not be restocked.

The Energy Intensive Users Group, which represents steelmakers and papermakers, said: "We have seen gas prices rise by 50% this year already and have been having a private fuel crisis which is only just registering with politicians now."
Terry Macalister

Local services

Local authorities have begun suspending non-essential public services amid mounting concern that the continued blockade of refineries and oil depots could soon start to force school closures in some parts of Britain.

Council leaders urged ministers to ensure that any emergency powers were used to direct fuel resources to priority areas such as fire services, refuse collection and care services for the elderly and other vulnerable people.

Emergency plans have already been drawn up by councils to eke out dwindling fuel stocks by dropping non-essential services such as mobile libraries, grass cutting and street cleaning.

In Devon, as in other rural areas, bus operators are being advised not to take children to school unless they know they have enough fuel for the return journey.

In Somerset, three rural primary schools will be closed today because staff are unable to get there. Free schoool meals for 10,000 children have been suspended and hundreds of pupils will miss school because some bus companies have run out of fuel.

In Leeds, 1,300 children at 11 special schools have been told their bus service may stop. In Essex, 44 pupils at De La Salle secondary school in Basildon woke up to be told their school bus would not be running. In Nottingham, two private bus companies providing school transport are running out of fuel.
Geoff Gibbs

Tourism

Tourist operators in rural areas said yesterday they were facing a disastrous collapse in bookings unless the fuel crisis was resolved in the next few days.

Chris Collier, chief executive of the Cumbria tourist board, said scores of small businesses were likely to fold as holidaymakers rushed to cancel bookings in the Lake District, amid fears that they would become stranded without petrol.

She said the tourist board had been inundated by calls from worried hoteliers, including the owner of a bed and breakfast who reported taking cancellations worth £2,500 in the space of a morning.

"The situation is extremely serious for Cumbria," she said. "September and October are traditionally our busiest months, and 95% of our visitors come by car."

One hotelier in Ambleside said he had lost £1,400 in cancelled bookings in 24 hours. Michael Fletcher, owner of the Nanny Brow country house hotel on Windermere, said he had only a week's supply of fuel oil left to heat the 18-bedroom hotel, and had asked guests to ration the number of baths they take. "We have quite a lot of staff here and we have to run the place whether we have 25 guests or 10 guests. If we're still in the same situation next week it will start to bite very hard indeed," he said.

Simon Bradley, the head of operations at South-west Tourism, said the situation was "very serious" for the economies of Devon and Cornwall. "We depend heavily on tourism in this region - in some areas it is the major employer," he said. "Undoubtedly, visitors are deciding not to come and that makes it absolutely crucial that this situation is resolved. September is a critical month." One major tourist operator in the south-west said it was laying on accomodation at rock bottom prices in case holidaymakers were stranded without enough fuel to travel home.

News of the fuel crisis is beginning to affect bookings from overseas, the British Tourist Authority said, with holidaymakers and business travellers thinking twice about coming to Britain while the shortages continue.

The oil companies were on a collision course with Tony Blair last night over their failure to dispatch tankers from storage depots immediately to replenish the country's empty petrol stations.

With a relatively small number of pickets managing to immobilise Britain, some ministers privately accused the companies of either colluding with the protesters or taking a line of no resistance.

Police around the country insist that there is free movement in most areas and only limited picketing. But outside some depots small groups of protesters are discussing with managers which deliveries should be allowed and giving "dispensations" only to fuel for the emergency services.

After crisis talks in Downing Street, John Prescott gave a hint of the government's frustration by telling the companies that it was their responsibility to ensure that supplies got to the forecourts.

Ray Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers Association, said it was right to ask why tankers were being kept in the depots despite the fact that the police had cleared almost all the blockades.

"It is reasonable to postulate that the oil companies have made a collective decision not to send out their tankers. We have to establish whether there is a real picket line and there is danger to the drivers, or if it is just protesters. And if there is no picket line, then you would be perfectly right to ask why not."

The government's anger was underlined by Lord Mackenzie, a former senior policeman who now advises the home secretary, Jack Straw, on law and order, who said he was baffled that tankers were not leaving depots.

"It does not add up to me," he said. "The people who are demonstrating, in a sense, I suppose, are supporters of the Conservative party. There's something not right about it. It's not a normal demonstration and they should get their sleeves rolled up and start delivering the oil where it belongs, at the petrol stations."

Lord Mackenzie, a senior officer during the l984-5 miners' strike, said many protests seemed so minimal that they could not be regarded as picketing. "Roads are often not blocked - if they were, the police would not hesitate in arresting people," he said. "It seems to be the companies causing the difficulty, and there does seem some collusion with the protesters. Perhaps it's because if the fuel duty was reduced they would sell more petrol."

With conspiracy theories flying thick and fast, Dave Bryan, the TGWU transport union national officer representing truckers, said tankers were idle "because there has been a number of incidents in recent days where drivers have been physically abused by motorists and even followed home there is evidence of intimidation".

When the Guardian contacted several leading oil companies, they maintained a common line. Asked why their tankers were not leaving refineries and depots, a spokeswoman for Shell - more than half of whose 1,100 stations are running dry - said: "We are concerned for the safety of our drivers and do not want to take any risk."

Asked what threats drivers were facing, she mentioned an "incident" last Friday in which a traffic cone was thrown at a tanker.

BP, with close to three quarters of its 1,500 stations out of action, came close to hinting it that was the victim of a government-inspired smear campaign, and said tankers would only leave depots with a police escort.

The oil companies have been making bumper profits as the result of soaring crude prices, but not from the higher pump prices. Their profit margins on the forecourt are slim because of intense competition .

Their profit comes from the rise in wholesale price of the oil they sell on to other corporations. They would like to see the government reduce the cut it takes at the petrol pump to stop consumer anger.

In theory the companies can take out injunctions to remove the protesters from their depots and refineries.

Andrew Ward, the corporate communications manager of TotalElfFina, told the BBC: "We have investigated the legal implications of this. We are advised injunctions would be difficult because the protest is not by an official union presence, so therefore it would be difficult to serve injunctions, because we would have to serve many injunctions on individuals."

Told that the police were saying that the roads were free of illegal picketing, he replied: "We are at the moment liaising with police on a terminal basis to try and get our vehicles out of the terminals."

Later, a company spokesman said "The mood of the protesters is fairly amicable, and if we were to send drivers out it might change. Getting fuel to the pumps would only solve the short-term problem and not deal with the original concerns of protesters."

Trade union leaders yesterday queued up to condemn the petrol protesters and called for pickets breaking the law to be arrested.

General secretaries criticised the blockades after hearing reports that nurses, council staff and other employees had been told to stay at home.

Bill Morris, head of the Transport and General Workers Union, said: "This campaign has crossed the line from democracy to anarchy. If they are breaking the law, the protesters should be arrested."

The most effective industrial action for years is overshadowing the annual TUC congress in Glasgow and risks embarrassing a sidelined labour movement.

While union delegates discussed training and partnerships with business yesterday, the demonstrators they opposed were triggering Tony Blair's biggest industrial crisis.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB, said the government would have faced even bigger problems if the unions were involved. But the unions' problem is that they are not involved. Instead they are watching helplessly as farmers, self employed drivers and hauliers make the running.

An embarrassed senior official in one of Britain's biggest unions joked that the TUC should launch a "let us work" campaign against employers in revenge for the 1926 General Strike or, in the spirit of true partnership, join their bosses on the picket lines.

Most union leaders have little sympathy with the non-union drivers and firms. They recall that lorry drivers have repeatedly driven through picket lines.

Danny Bryan, national secretary of the TGWU's road transport group, accused some pickets of bully-boy tactics. "We have evidence of the windscreen of a lorry being smashed over the weekend, our drivers being physically abused and there are rumours of drivers being followed to their houses," he said.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of the Unison public service staff union, contrasted the support of Tory tabloids for the oil blockade with their opposition to union strikes.

The oil giants, added Mr Bickerstaffe, would almost certainly take legal action against unions if they took industrial action before winning a ballot.

"The vast majority of these pickets are self employed. I'm not saying that there is a conspiracy but I believe that there is an unwritten agreement with the petrol companies."

Steve Pickering, the GMB deputy general secretary, said: "It is an amazing situation when bosses are picketing the workers. It would be strange if small businesses and Tory spokespeople were to force concessions by the same tactics they so vehemently denounced during the 1980s."

David Blunkett's invocation yesterday of the Winter of Discontent - the industrial explosion that helped sink the last Labour government and the party's bitterest crisis of the past half century - is an unmistakable sign of ministers' determination not to let the hauliers' oil blockade run out of control.

"We are all bound by history," he warned. "We all remember the 'Crisis, what crisis?' of 30 years ago."

The words Crisis, what crisis? - which actually came 21 years ago - were the Sun's headline caricaturing prime minister Jim Callaghan's apparent nonchalance as he returned from a world summit in Guadeloupe: it epitomised the media onslaught which helped to create a lasting mythology about the strikes.

The wave of stoppages dur ing the winter of 1978-79 was targeted at a 5% government pay norm at a time when inflation was almost double that. It followed two years of pay restraint which had seen millions of workers' wages fall in real terms.

After the TUC and Labour conferences voted to reject a third year of real pay cuts, one group of workers after another walked out in protest. Ford and bakery workers were followed by railway workers, and petrol tanker and road haulage drivers. By January they had been joined by more than a million low-paid council workers.

The pay limit - seen in retrospect as a mistake by the Labour ministers who tried to impose it - was broken.

Disruption was widespread, compounded by intensive picketing, and was mercilessly exploited by the opposition leader, Margaret Thatcher. But much of the reporting - of bodies left unburied, for example - was wildly exaggerated.

Certainly the 1979 lorry drivers' strikes were a very different industrial phenomenon from the current protests by owner-drivers and farmers against fuel prices and taxes, and, despite dire predictions at the time, their impact on consumers was less dramatic.

This week's blockades of fuel depots and refineries are being organised largely by small groups of self-employed hauliers, with apparent toleration from some oil companies and the indulgence of Conservative politicians and newspapers, in support of lower taxes.

The pay revolt of 21 years ago was staged by millions of workers, many of them among the lowest-paid in Britain, to head off a further squeeze on their living standards.

In the short term at least, it was also successful.

The outcome of the current fuel tax protests remains to be seen.

Returning from the UN special assembly in New York last week, Tony Blair was relatively confident that his government would see off the just-gathering petrol blockades.

In a private conversation, President Jacques Chirac had told him that the French government would not make concessions to the farmers and hauliers paralysing his country. It seemed to Mr Blair that this might even be the moment when the Socialist French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, confronted the labour unions and irrevocably joined the Blairite Third Way.

By the weekend Mr Blair was rudely disappointed as Mr Jospin succumbed first to the fishermen and then to the hauliers.

Just as capital has globalised, so has protest. It gave fresh heart to the nascent demonstrations in Britain.

But at Chequers Mr Blair had other things on his mind. He had sent troops to fight in the Sierra Leone jungle, and he had to brace himself for the potentially damaging serialised books portraying a feuding cabinet and a jealous chancellor.

Over the weekend he held two conversations with Gordon Brown, and they agreed that the best solution was to put pressure on Opec members, particularly the Saudis, to bring the price of oil down to as low as $24 a barrel.

Caught out

Mr Brown, who had been repeatedly warned by Scottish Labour MPs of the danger of the high petrol prices, promised that he would ensure that EU finance ministers stood firm against fuel tax cuts. The pressure on Opec to increase output would remain.

In retrospect, Whitehall admits that it was slow to recognise the speed with which the crisis would escalate. Mentally, ministers remembered the miners' strike of 1984-5 and the unions' failure to halt energy supplies. No one foresaw the scale of the menace ahead. One reason for that, it seems, is that there is no coordinating machinery to report to ministers that garage forecourts could be pumped dry.

By Sunday, however, it was apparent that panic buying was starting to eat into supplies much faster than expected, especially in the north and Wales. It was agreed that Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, should convene an emergency meeting of the civil contingencies committee.

It was also agreed that Mr Blair should go ahead with a two-day visit to the midlands and Yorkshire, designed to highlight the burgeoning dot.com economy. Cancelling would be to betray signs of panic and increase the run on petrol.

The visit rapidly developed a surreal quality. The more Mr Blair enthused about the increasing pace of internet traffic in Britain, the slower vehicle traffic moved around the country. Privately, he knew that two of his industry ministers had rushed to Balmoral for the Queen's consent to invoke emergency powers.

He had decided that he faced a battle of wills. There would be no change in petrol duty outside the normal budgetary cycle. He would not meet the protesters, or even the Road Haulage Association. The price of petrol was not out of line with Europe, and in any case the farmers did not pay special levies.

The country would have to be patient as the oil price came down. In Thatcherite tones, he told colleagues that he would not be held to ransom. "We cannot allow what happened in France to happen here."

But there was also a mystery. His Whitehall planners had told him there were enough oil refineries, and enough of them unblocked, to ensure a proper flow of petrol. The picketing was good-natured and did not represent a genuine unlawful blockade, the police had reported. The oil companies said their drivers feared physical intimidation if they went through the picket lines.

Mr Blair concluded that there needed to be greater coordination between the oil companies and the police.The police said the depot exits could be cleared if the tanker drivers were willing to use them. The oil companies said otherwise: the safety of their drivers was paramount.

Why were the oil companies refusing to ask their drivers to go through the picket lines? One view in government circles is that oil company drivers have a lot of sympathy with the hauliers. They do the same job, share the same motorway cafes, and know that many hauliers are close to the financial edge. Some political sources pointed out that the oil companies had little economic stake in preserving the current level of petrol duty.

By mid-evening he knew his tour was becoming untenable. The last straw came when he had to pull out of a dinner to celebrate John Prescott's 30 years as a Hull MP: protesters had blocked the routes to the restaurant with their cars. He drove back to the Sheffield Hilton where, in further overnight conversations, it was agreed that he had to return to London.

The Education Secretary, David Blunkett, was left to spell out the eerie historical parallels with the Winter of Discontent. He said: "We are all bound in by our history and we all remember the 'Crisis? What crisis?' of 30 years ago. The Prime Minister needs to be able to sit down, take the necessary advice and to decide what measures need to be taken. We are on the edge of a very real problem. The problem we face is panic buying. We need to ask people to be very calm, not [to] believe we are going to run out of petrol."

By lunchtime Mr Blair was in Downing Street discussing the crisis with Mr Prescott; the Chief Secretary, Andrew Smith; the police; civil servants; the Industry Secretary, Mr Byers; and Mr Straw. Once again he focused on the companies' refusal to distribute petrol and decided to speak to their chief executives personally.

At lunchtime Mr Prescott finally made the government's anger clear. "We are quite convinced that the oil companies can face up to their responsibilities to see that oil is distributed properly."

The special powers:

 The Queen has given the government unprecedented powers to assume control of fuel distribution to keep the emergency services going: the cabinet's emergency contingency committee can instruct oil companies to deliver to ambulances, hospitals and schools

 Ministers on the committee are expected to list up to 200 filling stations solely for the emergency services. Police will be in attendance in case of protests

 If necessary the provision can be extended to buses and supermarkets to ensure that food supplies are maintained

 At the Balmoral Privy Council meeting the Queen approved an order in council to set in motion the powers "because there is imminent in the United Kingdom a threatened emergency affecting fuel supplies which make it necessary in Her Majesty's Opinion that the government should temporarily have at its disposal exceptional powers for controlling the sources and availability of energy"

 If protesters refuse to let oil tankers leave refineries, the government could fall back on a 1,500-mile network of pipes, normally used to to distribute fuel to military bases, to distribute civilian fuel

Nicholas Watt and Michael White

Six days ago there was nothing more to be seen than a cloud over Cheshire, the size of a band of farmers on a freelance expedition to try to shut down a single refinery. Now there is raging crisis: the prime minister back in London, having called off all other engagements to take charge of the government response; petrol supplies exhausted throughout the capital and forecasts that very soon none will be left anywhere in the country. How could this autumn of discontent have blown up so fast out of nowhere?

The government was all too clearly unprepared for the scale of it. On Monday evening, as the lights went out in service stations all over Britain, Mr Blair was still trying to keep a dinner date with John Prescott in Hull. Ministers had badly underestimated the forces ranged against them. What had begun as a rising of the Poujadist self-employed, a political constituency with which past Labour governments might have been only too happy to do battle, was now looking much more formidable. People whose roads were obstructed, who were forced to sit for hours in queues to fill up their tanks, seemed on the whole more upset by the chancellor's tax take than they were with those causing disruption. Whatever they thought of the tactics, they welcomed action which if successful would cut their own petrol bills.

So the government's message of "no surrender, wait for the budget" failed to find many takers. Nor did it play too well at the TUC yesterday, as Gordon Brown insisted that Labour must not amend its strategy to deal with an oil price increase which might prove only temporary. The trouble is that all experts see prices continuing to climb; none predicts a slipping back to acceptable levels. But by now, pertinent questions were surfacing as to how and why the protest movement has achieved such swift, overpowering success. Why have the pumps run dry when the picketing in many places was light, verging on vestigial? Why have oil companies made so little apparent effort to lift what in many places was hardly more than a token siege? Why, where the police had cleared the barricades out of the way, was nothing, even now, moving? One analyst even alleged that oil companies wanted to see the demonstrations succeed, in the hope that the chancellor would be forced to cut tax, thus boosting their takings.

The sun must have come out in Downing Street as the first signs appeared that the focus of public disquiet was switching from government unreadiness to oil company duplicity. But that could yet switch back again. Beyond Tony Blair's upbeat assessment and promised measures last night, he and Mr Brown need to move fast and purposefully to recapture control of the agenda. They need to be far more robust in defending taxes on petrol as essential to protect our threatened environment. They need to show that the Treasury's windfall from petrol price increases (a mere £400m in the past year, the chancellor says) will not simply disappear into the Treasury's maw, but be used for the public's long-term benefit through spending on enhanced public transport and investment in alternative sources of power. They must also resist the temptation to talk, as Jack Straw regrettably did yesterday, as if all street demonstrations, whatever their cause, constitute a form of disruption which society should not tolerate. Where disruption takes forms which are clearly illegal, there must be action to stop it. Where it is merely troublesome and discomforting for authority, no government with any liberal pretensions should try to deny its legitimacy.

A German friend told me how she had once gone to see an English acquaintance at her workplace.

As she was taking off her coat she asked who the Africans were in the outer office. Her English acquaintance was nonplussed.

"Africans?" she asked. "Yes. You must know they're there - all those black people taking down files and writing out forms."

"Oh, them," said the Englishwoman. "No. They're not Africans. They're British."

My German friend says it was a moment that changed her whole outlook on a part of life.

"For the first time, I realised you could have a concept of citizenship that was completely separate from the idea of ethnic origin."

Her anecdote is particularly relevant in the week in which a new commission, headed by the respected Christian Democrat politician, Rita Süssmuth, starts work on a what promises to be a lengthy review of Germany's laws on nationality and immigration.

German, like Britain, has begun to suspect that it needs more, nor less, immigrants for its economic wellbeing.

But in Germany, to a far greater extent than in Britain, the issue is bedevilled by the concept of citizenship which my friend had unwittingly carried around with her till the day she went to that office in London.

But then it was only last year that a law was introduced by Gerhard Schröder's centre-left coalition to break the bond between blood and nationality.

It allowed foreigners to become citizens after living in Germany for eight years, provided they gave up their existing passport.

Those who had been born in Germany of foreign parents could keep dual citizenship, but were obliged to choose which to keep by the age of 23.

By the time it became law, the measure had been watered down in response to bitter resistance, including a petition got up by the opposition Christian Democrats.

The new nationality law cost the Social Democrats, the senior partners in the ruling coalition, a defeat in the first regional vote to be held after their general election victory - a result which, in turn, cost them their majority in the regionally appointed upper house.

Like my friend, Germans of all classes and persuasions had been conditioned by the fact that, for years, both main parties subscribed to the view that Germany - to use the stock phrase - was "not a country of immigration".

It was thus neither feasible nor desirable for people to be both black and German.

Or to be German and, say, Turkish or Serbian or Italian by origin. Even if you had been born in Germany and spoke accentless German, you could not be a German citizen unless your parents were.

Yet the country was, and is, teeming with people of foreign origin. More than seven million of Germany's 82m inhabitants are what, in other countries, would be called immigrants. But not here.

One group is made up of the workers from Mediterranean Europe who provided the cheap labour for the "economic miracle" and their families.

For decades, the politicians sustained the myth that they would one day go home. They were thus not immigrants, but "Gastarbeiter" (guest workers).

The other group was made up of those who had been accepted since. But they were let in as asylum seekers. The authorities knew full well that most were not genuine political refugees.

According to official estimates, only five per cent of those who entered in the early 1990s were fleeing political persecution. But, again, the important thing was to sustain the idea that Germany was "not a country of immigration".

One result is that Germans continue to refer to the seven million people of foreign origin in their midst, as "foreigners" or, at best, "Mitbürger".

At first, that sounds fine. Its dictionary definition is "co-citizen". But then, strictly speaking, "Mitarbeiter" means "co-worker", and in practice it is used as a euphemism for "employee".

The unspoken tenent is that Germany's foreigners are in the country on sufferance. It is one that infuses all areas of life, as the setting up of the Süssmuth commission on immigration demonstrated.

Until the fact was pointed out by irate leaders of the Turkish community, it had no one on it to represent the views of Germany's almost non-exisitent immigrants.

If all had gone according to plan, today, September 13, would have seen the birth of the state of Palestine, after a gestation period of more than 50 years.

But instead of a state - whose due date was delayed for the second time at the weekend - there is the birth of a strange new vocabulary, the creation of those trying to solve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Their offerings include: divided sovereignty, joint sovereignty, shared sovereignty, delayed sovereignty, suspended sovereignty, functional sovereignty, custodial sovereignty and extraterritorial sovereignty.

Because while the battle of sovereignty may seem archaic in an age of globalisation and free trade, this is the Holy Land, where religion, history and sacred sites complicate everything.

The newly minted terminology is intended to apply to the Haram al-Sharif, as Muslims call it, or Temple Mount as it is called by the Jews.

The site, within the walls of the old city of Jerusalem, is revered equally by Muslims and Jews, and claimed with equal passion by Israelis and Palestinians.

The Haram, which contains the shimmering gold Dome of the Rock and al-Aqsa mosques, is the third holiest shrine in Islam, after Mecca and Medina.

For Jews, it is the most sacred soil on the planet, the site of their temple, which was destroyed in 70 AD except for the Wailing Wall, and is visited by hundreds of worshippers every day.

The panoply of definitions, which have come into wide circulation in the last two months, represent attempts by those trying to solve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to strip the notion of sovereignty of its emotional charge.

The logic behind the lexicon is to finesse the present understandings of sovereignty so that both sides can claim victory in the most intractable of their disputes, thus overcoming the single most formidable obstacle to peace in the Middle East.

Today, Israeli radio talk shows invented yet another definition: vertical sovereignty. However, that may just be a fancy way of describing subterranean sovereignty.

That would see the Palestinians declared the masters of the Haram al-Sharif from the ground up, granting them control of the plateau where the mosques stand, but leaving Israel in control of the ground beneath, where the ruins of the temple are believed to lie.

Or humans could simply appeal to the almighty to take the whole dispute off their hands: divine sovereignty.

That would grant God title to the Haram, leaving mere mortals with the task of delegating responsibility for such human concerns as policing, rubbish collection, and the issuing of renovation permits for the holy site.

The inspiration for such creative solutions to the future dispensation of the Haram has come from some unexpected quarters - the frozen ice cap of Antarctica, a US naval base in the Caribbean, and the secessionist-minded Canadian province of Quebec.

At one point, Israeli academics were considering the International Law of the Sea as a possible model for land-locked Jerusalem.

The treaty assigns rights to oil, gas and fishing up to 12 miles beyond a country's shoreline - or "functional sovereignty".

Then there is "qualified sovereignty" or "relative sovereignty", which describes the extra autonomy enjoyed by the Canadian province of Quebec.

Although such ideas are engaging, many Israelis - including the former prime minister and Nobel peace prize laureate, Shimon Peres, has dismissed these efforts are word play.

They are seen as far less benign by Palestinians, who accuse Israel of presenting these ideas as fancy formulas to prevent Yasser Arafat from exercising full sovereignty over all areas of East Jerusalem occupied by Israel since 1967.

Some of the Israeli proposals would merely sanction the status quo, under which, Israel has exercised ultimate security control over the Haram, while the Palestinians, through the Muslim Waqf, or property trust, are in charge of daily administration.

As might have been predicted, the welter of definitions has encouraged imitators, although some are less than earnest.

When the idea of God's sovereignty, which was first raised by Jordan in the mid-90s was aired in the Israeli press, some commentators were less than reverential.

"Which God should get sovereignty? The Lord of Hosts, Allah or the father of Jesus?" asked Zvi Barel, an Arab affairs columnist for Ha'aretz newspaper.

"Maybe the best idea of all would be to transfer sovereignty over the entire Temple Mount compound to the Disney company so it could build a Park of Holies there."

TUC leaders yesterday accused the government of undermining its campaign for entry to the euro by watering down improved employment rights and denying UK workers benefits enjoyed by the rest of Europe.

But efforts to unite British unions behind a compromise policy on the single currency, before the general election, fell apart when Bill Morris, leader of the TGWU, and Sir Ken Jackson of the AEEU, reignited their public row over how to handle the issue.

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB general union, said the best way for the government to fight its pro-Europe campaign was to set out a vision of a Europe that brought social progress and benefits.

"But, frankly, it does not help us to build a positive case for Europe if the TUC has to keep taking the British government to the European court of justice to win back employment rights which are clearly enshrined in European directives and which are freely accepted elsewhere in Europe," he said. "I would like to see [this] Labour government leading Europe on social improvements, not being the last in a very long convoy expressing arrogant disapproval."

The TUC is appalled that the government cut the three to four weeks annual holiday guaranteed under EU law to take account of public holidays, and won public backing from Anna Diamantopoulou, the Brussels employment and social affairs commissioner, for its stance.

Ms Diamantopoulou told the annual congress in Glasgow that the UK had a poor track record on social partnership, whereas the EU envisaged a much longer role for unions in collective bargaining on issues such as new forms of jobs, and favoured modern regulation rather than deregulation. The EU's social policy agenda, she said, was critical to the success of transforming Europe into a 10,000bn-euro economy, with living standards up 25%, within the next five years.

Tony Dubbins, leader of the GPMU print union, said: "To persuade people to vote for the euro, it has to be integrated with a government commitment to underwrite and extend the social dimension."

The united front shown by unions backing the euro collapsed when Mr Morris said the British people could not be "bullied or bounced" into adopting the single currency. He said: "There is no majority in the country for the single currency. No wonder, because we have a strong economy and a stable currency. Investors have confidence in our country despite some of us running Britain down. Foreign investment rose last year by 25%."

Sir Ken, the target of this jibe, insisted that foreign investors had warned him and Tony Blair they would pull out of Britain if the government did not clarify its position on the euro. He said of Mr Morris that he was "the only man who can support the chancellor and the shadow chancellor [Michael Portillo] on the same day".

Mr Morris's approach was echoed by a fervent anti-euro proponent, Fawzi Abrahim of the college lecturers' union, Natfhe, who said the motion was "tainted" because it did not represent the views of the trade union movement.

"It talks of ensuring members understand the benefits of joining as if they were stupid, but they do understand," he said, pointing out that two years of TUC campaigning had produced more people opposed to UK entry.

The only thing that united the TUC was the common view that Britain could not join at the exchange rate of DM3.20. That was "a suicide note for much of our economy", said Mr Edmonds, who saw it as a compelling reason against immediate entry. Unions now favour an entry rate of about DM2.80.

The United Nations security council is to agree a resolution on Friday to increase its peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone from 13,000 to 20,000, a move it is hoped will end the bitter dispute between the Indians and Nigerians over leadership.

Diplomats see the increase as an opportunity to remove the controversial Indian commander of the UN force in Sierra Leone, Major-General Vijay Jetley, who is due to finish his term in November.

A memo leaked to the Guardian last weekend revealed him to be at loggerheads with the Nigerian contingent. The Nigerians are now threatening not to serve under him.

Ambassadors representing the UN security council members met in New York on Monday to discuss the Sierra Leone crisis.

The draft resolution they agreed, which they described as close to the final version that will go before the security council on Friday, will not only increase the size of the peacekeeping force but widen its remit and change the command structure.

The strengthened force will increase the UN's annual bill for Sierra Leone from an estimated $400m (£285m) to $780m (£555m).

The Nigerians will be pleased to see Gen Jetley lose the command. But, in a move that will anger the Nigerians, some permanent members of the security council are pushing for another Indian to replace him. The final decision will be made by the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan.

One diplomat, with inside information about the negotiations at the UN, said that although the Nigerians had the biggest contingent, there was resistance to giving them the command.

Mr Annan warned on Monday that the UN, the government of Sierra Leone and west African nations must "harmonise" their work if peace is to be restored to Sierra Leone.

The draft resolution notes "with concern serious shortfalls in capability encountered by Unamsil (the UN mission in Sierra Leone) in the recent past with regard to the command and control, equipment, training and preparation of military personnel and the implementation of rules of engagement".

It adds that success of the mission will depend on "an effective command and control structure and capacity, a single chain of command and the commitment to implement the mandate".

That mandate is to be made clearer: to respond robustly to any hostile action and "to extend state authority, restore law and order and further stabilise the situation progressively throughout the entire country".

Gen Jetley's memo complained that Nigerian politicians and soldiers had been sabotaging the peace effort in order to prolong the profits they were making from illegally trading in diamonds from Sierra Leone.

In response to the accusations, the Nigerian chief of army staff, Major-General Victor Malu, said his army could no longer serve under Gen Jetley and has demanded his immediate removal.

"We are not going to serve under that man in whatever circumstances. If he is not removed, he will not get our cooperation, and we are the largest contingent in the force," he said.

The two most senior Nigerian officials implicated in the report - Mr Annan's special representative in Freetown, under-secretary-general Oluyemi Adeniji, and Gen Jetley's immediate subordinate, Brigadier General Mohammed Garba - have both denounced the memo.

The increase in the number of troops to 20,000 means a higher-ranking soldier than Gen Jetley will be required. Western diplomats see that as a stroke of luck as it provides an excuse for his removal but they are equally adamant that he will not be replaced by any of the existing Nigerian commanders in Sierra Leone, whom they regard as being equally culpable for the row.

"You'd have to say that all of their positions are untenable," said one senior UN official. "Jetley clearly does not command the confidence of the largest contingent in his force. The Nigerians have stopped just short of saying they won't obey his orders. But there is also a strong feeling among the other contingents that whatever Jetley's shortcomings as a commander he is basically right about the Nigerians.

"There are not many here who want to be commanded by them because they don't trust them to serve the interests of Sierra Leone or the UN."

After the Guardian's revelations, Gen Malu responded by accusing Gen Jetley of "trying to justify his ineptitude, inaction and inefficiency in the leadership of a multinational force" and that he is resentful of the Nigerians because they opposed the "dominance of Indian generals" at the UN's headquarters in Freetown.

Gen Jetley, who has been resting in New Delhi after suffering from malaria, has said he cannot recall writing the report and declined to comment. The UN insists that he will be returning to his post next week despite considerable speculation in his Freetown headquarters that the general will not be back.

The increasingly accident-prone Bush presidential campaign was accused of dirty tricks yesterday, after it was discovered that the word "rats" appeared subliminally in a Republican political broadcast targeting Democratic health care proposals.

The offending word, in large white capital letters, flashes against a black background for a thirtieth of a second as a woman narrator criticises Vice President Al Gore's plan for government funding of prescriptions for pensioners.

George W Bush ridiculed as "bizarre and weird" accusations that his campaign was trying to use such underhand techniques to discredit his opponent. Yesterday, however, he announced that the $2.5m (£1.3m) advertising campaign would be withdrawn.

Alex Castellanos, the Republican campaigner responsible for producing the advertisment denied trying to send subliminal messages.

"We don't play ball that way. I'm not that clever," he said.

However, Mr Castellanos has been involved in controversial political broadcasts before. In 1990 he produced an advertisement for the rightwing Republican senator for North Carolina, Jesse Helms, which used racial imagery in a contest with a black businessman, Harvey Gant. At one point a white pair of hands receives a job rejection letter and crumples it up, but for a fraction of a second the letter fades to a picture of Mr Gant and the hands appear to be crushing his head.

Kathleen Hall Jamieson, who analyses the advertisement in her book Dirty Politics: Deception, Distraction and Democracy, said Mr Castellanos insisted then that the imagery was accidental. Ms Jamieson believes the Helms advertisement was the first instance of subliminal imagery in US political advertising and Mr Castellanos's "rats advertisement" is the second.

Gore campaign workers were scarcely able to contain their glee yesterday as the Bush campaign was forced into emergency damage limitation for the second time in eight days, at a time when it is losing ground in the polls.

Last Monday - apparently unaware that he was speaking close to a live microphone - Mr Bush was overheard describing a New York Times reporter as "a major-league asshole". The reporter, Adam Clymer, had written a critical account of the Texas governor's record on health care, and the gaffe made Mr Bush appear peevish and unsettled.

Campaigning in Florida yesterday, the candidate seemed rattled by the new controversy yesterday, struggling to pronounce the word "subliminal", and raising doubts as to whether he understood its meaning when he argued: "The idea of one frame out of 900 hardly in my judgment makes a conspiracy."

After seeing a double-digit lead in the polls evaporate in less than a month, splits have emerged in the Bush camp over how to pursue the campaign, and when to "go negative". Last week the candidate's staff were trying to increase their control over the Republican National Committee's campaign office responsible for producing political broadcasts, because it was unhappy about the harshly negative tone of some of its output.

Mr Castellanos insisted that the word had appeared accidentally as part of a visual effect which broke up words from campaign slogans into fragments and flashed them across the screen. The word "rats" was supposed to be part of "bureaucrats", he said.

In the controversial segment of the advertisement, other words and groups of letters appear before the slogan "The Gore Prescription Plan: Bureaucrats Decide" crystallises on the screen. However, the word "rats" is larger than the other word-fragments.

The word was spotted only after 4,400 screenings in 33 regions, by a Democratic supporter in Seattle, Gary Greenup, who alerted his local party.

"Initially, I was just kind of intrigued... but when I taped it and looked it I thought this is not really very good. It's somewhat underhand and a little bit devious and it should be brought to light."

The government has agreed to give the public some form of access to details of sex offenders, the parents of the murdered eight-year-old schoolgirl Sarah Payne said yesterday.

Emerging after an hour-long meeting with the Home Office minister Paul Boateng, Michael and Sara Payne said he had agreed to their request for a version of a "Sarah's law", giving parents access to the sex offenders register.

Outside the Home Office headquarters in central London, Mrs Payne said: "We have been assured there will be a Sarah's law. We are very happy indeed. It's what we were all working so hard for. Unfortunately we haven't got our daughter, but it might help somebody else's."

Mr and Mrs Payne refused to give further details of assurances made by Mr Boateng.

A Home Office spokeswoman said: "There were constructive discussions between Mr Boateng and the family of Sarah Payne. The proposed direction of government policy was part of those discussions. We expect to make an announcement shortly."

She refused to give further details of what had been agreed or to confirm claims that Mr Boateng had promised to introduce a Sarah's law.

Ministers have been looking at ways to strengthen police powers to deal with paedophiles, expected to be announced this month. These could allow police to photograph and question offenders on the register, and possibly authorise police to enter and search their homes.

But the plans had been expected to stop short of a Sarah's law - based on the US Megan's law, named for a schoolgirl killed by a paedophile in California in 1994 - making the names and addresses of sex offenders public.

Access to the information varies from state to state. In some states, names and pictures can be downloaded from a police website.

There has been scepticism over how effective Megan's law has been in stopping offenders repeating their crimes. The law has also been undermined by vigilante attacks.

In Britain only the police and certain other officials have access to the sex offenders' register. It has a higher compliance rate of offenders keeping it updated than US equivalents.

The former Tory home secretary, Michael Howard, said he had considered a British version of Megan's law in 1997 when the sex offences register was launched, but rejected the idea after advisers warned him of the dangers of paedophiles going to ground.

Lawyers have warned that the move could be challenged as a breach of the right to privacy guaranteed by the European convention on human rights.

The Paynes were whisked off in a Jaguar with the News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, and managing editor Stuart Kuttner, who also attended the meeting. The paper has been campaigning for the introduction of a Sarah's law.

This included "naming and shaming" people on the sex offenders register by publishing their details, a move thought to have led to vigilante attacks on innocent people.

Before the meeting, the Paynes handed the home secretary, Jack Straw, a 700,000-name petition calling for a Sarah's law, mainly from News of the World readers.

The couple, from Hersham, Surrey, said Mr Straw agreed to the need for tougher sentencing and more powers for families of victims.

Mr Payne said the massive public support for their campaign since their daughter was snatched on July 1 from a country lane near her grandparents' home in Kingston, West Sussex, had helped them cope with her death.

As battles for control of middling-sized British corporates go, the antics surrounding the future of our glorious 200 year-old London Stock Exchange take some beating.

Yesterday's admission that the merger with Deutsche Börse is dead in its current un-thought-through form was inevitable. The whole idea was badly planned and terribly presented from the outset.

With hindsight, one of the great howlers of the aborted iX deal was the idea that trading in "growth" companies go to Frankfurt, while blue chip trading was to reside in London. Who, one senior market man asked recently, might decide what is a growth company and what is not - since anyone who has the ability to spot them should have retired by now to somewhere warm and light on taxes.

The deal was not thought through in advance. So it is little surprise to learn now that the exchange's management did not feel capable of fending off the hostile approach from Sweden's OM, while simultaneously selling (if that is the word) the London-Frankfurt merger to their shareholders, who also double up as their customers.

The exchange is now a commercial business and has to play by the corporate rule-book. In turn, corporate precedent says that when a management sees its plans for the business trashed by the owners and then lands itself with an opportunistic approach from a predatory rival, the owners tend to move in and sack the managers. An experienced pair of hands is then installed who can be trusted with extracting value and/or rebuilding the confidence required to remain independent.

In the case of the exchange, this is a bit tricky, since the new chairman, Don Cruickshank, was supposed to be the very man. (And anyway, David James is much too busy folding up that tent in south east London.)

On the other hand, the position of Michael Marks, a board member and a grandee of the London stock market in every sense, is much clearer. It is untenable.

Traditionally, the authorities (including the exchange itself and the financial services authority) have always frowned on City advisers who sit on the boards of corporate clients. Whatever the Chinese walls, there is perceived to be a potential conflict of interest. In the case of Mr Marks, his firm, Merrill Lynch, is the exchange's prime corporate finance adviser as well as its biggest customer.

More to the point, whether he likes it or not, Mr Marks is credited as the architect of the iX merger. He should resign now before the shareholders vote him off the podium at Thursday's annual general meeting.

But regardless of who sits around the exchange's boardroom table, mapping the future of this institution has not become any simpler after yesterday's events. The pressure for consolidation, in order to bring transaction costs down, is as great as ever. At the same time, there is no sign that the regulatory hurdles - where varying market rules, tax regimes, and supervisory structures in different jurisdictions make seamless cross-border equity trading impossible - are being dismantled.

This is an area where a confident London Stock Exchange, in partnership with the FSA, should be taking a European lead.

For all its flaws and technicalities and suspicious price movements, the London market remains rich in terms of integrity and practical experience - certainly when compared with any bourse on the continent. Sadly, rather than confidence, all any of us expect in the short term is more bureaucratic squabbling, with the occasional outburst of bluster.

Next lesson

Just 18 months ago, Next's finance director David Keens declared that people who wanted to choose clothes on the internet were "sad".

He dismissed the idea of putting the company's clothes catalogue online, because he thought Next's customers were too impatient to wait for pictures to download. Since Mr Keens' attack of foot-in-mouth disease, the group has put more than 1,200 pictures of shirts, skirts and jackets on the web. Next now expects more than £20m of online sales this year.

Mr Keens was guilty of underestimating the appeal of Next's unthreatening, classic clothes - even internet addicts want to get their hands on them.

Others have made a similar mistake - it has taken the City years to come round to the company.

Next has pulled off quite a feat by prospering while the rest of the middle-market has been suffering. Its secret is simple - each year it takes its unexciting range and just adds a few trendy twists. The company has stuck to one brand, avoiding the trap of diversifying into unknown areas. Others, such as Marks & Spencer, should watch and learn.

Celltech, Britain's biggest biotech company, yesterday moved into the black for the first time but saw its shares dive 5% as analysts branded its interim results "uninspiring".

The Slough-based group, which recently entered the FTSE 100 index, made profits of £10.7m before exceptional items, largely owing to its acquisition of drugs firm Medeva in January.

Finance director Peter Allen said: "These profits are a first for us but we're rather cautious about life. We view them as just a start."

By buying Medeva, Celltech added a sales network and a portfolio of mature drugs to its portfolio of emerging products. However, Medeva operating profits fell slightly during the period to £25.7m, owing to declining sales of its top three drugs.

Mr Allen said the fall was due to Celltech's policy of encouraging customers to keep lower stocks of the key drugs - methylphenidate for attention deficit disorder, Tussionex for flu and heart drug Zaroxolyn.

The figures were accompanied by the unexpected departure of Garry Watts, the former finance director of Medeva who was retained after the takeover to continue running the business. Mr Allen said: "We wanted somebody with more of a pharmaceutical background than an accounting background."

Initial sales of Mylotarg, the recently launched drug for leukaemia, reached $3.8m. But analysts were disappointed by a modest contribution from Chirocaine, the group's new anaesthetic. Mr Allen admitted that it would take time to establish, saying: "Anaesthetists are a relatively conservative bunch."

There was also concern at the size of a £349m goodwill charge on the purchase of Medeva. Eva Haas of Old Mutual Securities said: "I'm mildly disappointed with the results. Some people might say that the size of this goodwill charge means they rather drastically overpaid for Medeva."

Celltech's shares closed down 77p at £44.20. Steve McGarry of Goldman Sachs said: "There's nothing really here to excite the market."

Still the skies darken for the Millennium Dome and its ministerial chief, Lord Falconer. On the back of last week's £47m bail-out by national lottery money and the verdict of David James, the corporate fixer brought in as chairman to resuscitate the project, that the dome was built in the wrong place, too quickly and should probably not have been built at all, comes the news that Nomura, the Japanese bank which had been planning to buy the site for £105m, has pulled out of the deal. This appears to bring down the curtain on what had been the project's one bright prospect and makes the question of whether Lord Falconer has a right to continue in office more urgent.

Not that Nomura should escape blame. At first glance one might think that a bank which had offered hard cash and a realistic future as a theme park for the corpse of a dying attraction would be the wounded party. Far from it. Though Nomura abandoned the deal only after getting a comprehensive briefing from the author of a crucial report on the dome's financial position, this report (which neither Nomura nor the public have been allowed to see) is not the only cause of the breakdown. Its details have been known for some time and for the bank to cite them now as its excuse for quitting is unconvincing, as is talk of blaming 12 small holes in the building's great plastic roof. Some may suspect a mere negotiating ploy; after all, Nomura announced its decision as ministers reeled under a still greater crisis.

This, though, may not help Lord Falconer, whose continual refusals to resign begin to look foolish. Not long ago he had a viable defence: that the errors which doomed the dome occurred before he took office and that he had done all he could to save the project, not least by selling it to Nomura. Now that has been blown apart. Under his watch things have gone badly wrong, even as he has insisted that they were going right. Nor does he seem to have acted on these problems. It is stretching credibility to believe that he was not aware of the background to the inconsistencies cited by Nomura as a reason for abandoning the deal, yet he seems to have ignored them. The dome may yet end up with Nomura, or may be picked up by the Legacy consortium, whose hopeful bid the government previously rejected. Or it may even be bulldozed. What is increasingly hard to accept is that its fate should remain in the hands of Lord Falconer.

Jack Straw said this week that victims of crime or their relatives would be able to lay complaints under the new Human Rights Act if there was evidence police had failed to carry out a proper investigation of a crime. He said of the act, due to come into force on October 2: "It is about the rights of victims and the wider community".

But the home secretary is also considering giving victims a greater role in the judicial process. He has suggested that the court could be provided with a "victim personal statement". He is rightly sympathetic to the feelings of those who feel ignored in a process which directly affects them, but careful distinctions must be drawn. Helping victims by way of counselling or compensation is vital and doubtless much could be done to improve the support they receive; but the prosecution of the perpetrators of crime is another matter.

Protestors in Portsmouth who believe their children to be the target of child abusers have every right to air their views publicly but they have no role in the court's function of deciding guilt, innocence or punishment. Centuries have gone by since catching criminals was left largely to victims and their families. Punishment was seen as making reparation to the victim. In modern society, while reparation may still have its place, maintaining the rule of law has become the responsibility of the state. The whole process has become professionalised.

Jack Straw is certainly entitled to consider whether the pendulum has swung too far. Occasionally, reminders of the medieval rights of the victims have surfaced. In 1817, Abraham Thornton was tried by judge and jury for the rape and murder of Mary Ashford. They had been to a dance in the rural neigbourhood of Erdington, now a suburb of Birmingham, and they walked home together. Next morning Mary's violated body was found drowned in a pond. There were signs of a bloody struggle nearby. Abraham was the obvious suspect.

He claimed they had intercourse by agreement and then parted peacefully. He denied any involvement in her death. In the days before fingerprints, blood tests or DNA, the means of proof were lacking. The judge pointed out that there was no evidence to link the accused directly with the crime. The jury acquitted. In their grief, Mary's family tried to use an archaic legal procedure, "appeal of felony", to have Thornton re-arrested and brought before the Court of Queen's Bench. Thornton's lawyer arrived at court with a large pair of gloves which he handed to his client. Those who have seen the recent production of Richard II would recognise what happened next. Thornton threw down his gauntlet in front of Mary's brother, William Ashford.

Thornton claimed that the medieval law entitled him to trial by battle - the primitive idea was that winning a physical fight would prove who was right. Ashford refused the challenge - Thornton was younger and fitter. Ashford's lawyers argued that he should have a second jury trial but the judges said he had to fight or abandon his claim. Prudently he did so. The judges had rather effectively consigned the appeal of felony to the dustbin of history; it has never been attempted again.

The victim's family has no longer the right to challenge an acquittal. And why should the accused, who has stood trial and been acquitted, have to face another trial merely because the victim is unhappy at the outcome? Where a suspect has not been tried and acquitted and the the Crown Prosecution Service declines to prosecute, there remains the possibility of a private prosecution, but, as the family of Stephen Lawrence discovered, it has pitfalls.

The high standard of proof of guilt of crime must be achieved, yet the state's investigative resources are not available to the private person. As the Lawrences discovered to their dismay, an acquittal rules out a future public prosecution (though this could be changed following the recommendations of the Lawrence inquiry).

The Human Rights Act is opening up promising opportunities for victims of crime to put greater pressure on the police and prosecuting auhorities to take action. The right to a fair hearing enshrined in the European Human Rights Convention has already been held by the Court of Human Rights to entitle the victim of crime to demand a thorough investigation and hold the police accountable if it is not carried out. From next month the English courts will have to enforce this requirement; the Scottish courts already have to do so. It is also important to remember that the victim has the right to take civil proceedings for compensation but this has little value where the criminal has no means or they are effectively concealed.

The Criminal Injuries Compensation Board may provide more certain recompense but there are features of that system which may themselves fall foul of the Human Rights Act. Jack Straw is right to try to improve remedies for victims but, other than as a witness of fact, the victim has no proper voice at the trial of the alleged perpetrator. To give the victim a role in deciding innocence or guilt would flout our notion of impartial and independent justice. It would violate the right of the accused to a fair trial. To give the victim any right to influence the sentence would raise the same fair trial issue.

Within the criminal process itself the victim or the family may be able to contribute something to the sentencing process by providing information which will assist the judge. To this extent a "victim personal statement" may be of value. Beyond that, sympathy for the victim cannot in modern days detract from the state's responsibility to ensure the independence and impartiality of the justice system.

Every night in the city of Prague, up to 170 passengers squeeze on to a converted barge named the Secret. Crew members take them through an aeroplane-style safety drill, complete with life-vests and polystyrene floats, as the boat sets off along the Vltava river, accompanied by a Hungarian Gypsy band. The light fades; gnats dance in the boat's headlights.

This is not the Czech answer to the bteau-mouche, but rather the latest venture by Petr and Matej Forman, the identical twin sons of film director Milos Foreman. Petr calls it the Czech Millennium Dome. The pair have ploughed almost £130,000 of their own cash into this floating theatre with its all-singing, all-dancing puppet play, Secrets of the Crimson Sails - and so far they are losing money.

As the boat slides past the trams, the cubist villas and the soaring TV tower, a complex production unravels on the revolving stage: human actors cavort as floppy drunks, virtually indistinguishable from the life-size puppets with which they share the limelight; toy boats zoom over the audience's heads; merchants appear on stilts, unravelling multi-coloured silks that envelop the stage; and then, most enchanting of all, the stained-glass table tops in the stalls light up to reveal tiny doll's house-size scenes.

Written by the Russian storyteller Alexander Grin, this is the tale of Assol, a poor sailor's daughter convinced that one day a handsome prince will whisk her away on a ship with crimson sails. "It's about the fact that real life can also be like a fairytale, and that people can make miracles happen for others," says Petr. He and Matej say that after this project they know all about miracle-making. "Everyone said the project was mad from the outset," says Petr. "Even our dad said we'd bitten off more than we could chew."

The tale of the show's tortuous birth encompasses all the nightmares one might expect to face in a bureaucratic, cash-strapped and land-locked country. When the brothers came across an old communist-era barge rusting in a boat yard last year, they approached the ministry of transport with plans to turn it into a theatre boat, only to be confronted with unending lists of conditions. Now they are convinced they know enough about boats to qualify as waterways engineers.

Next came attempts to convince the culture ministry that the project was worth supporting. They had a chance to get their hands on extra cash because of Prague's status as a European City of Culture - but only if they could fight their way through Kafkaesque bureaucracy.

Carpenters, construction workers and craftspeople worked for months on the conversion, earning as little as 300 crowns (£5.50) a day. Once the boat was completed, the 22-strong team had become so involved the Formans couldn't bear to let them go. "They were an integral part of it, so we employed all of them as actors," says Petr. Apart from the twins, there are only three professional actors involved.

Petr and Matej attribute their remarkable achievement to the fact that they are twins. "We've got something that many people try and fail to find all their lives," says Petr. "I trust my brother 100% and we have a natural communication that helps the creative process and enables us to do crazy things." Indeed, so united are their thought processes that they initially insist that there's no point in my speaking to both of them.

The brothers, who live on separate floors of the same Prague house, bought for them by their father, stress that they are not alone in their latest venture. They are co-operating with the French cabaret theatre Dromesko and the Theatre National de Bretagne. After Prague, they plan to visit Hamburg, Dresden, Strasbourg, Amsterdam, Copenhagen and Nancy. And they are keen to find backers in London to help them negotiate the Thames.

Animation and skilful puppetry are traditions strongly associated with Bohemia. Under the Hapsburg empire, the Czech language was squeezed off the mainstream stage in favour of German, but was allowed to survive in puppet theatre. Under communism, the authorities considered puppetry mere child's play, so it was allowed to thrive almost unsupervised, giving directors the freedom to create some fascinating subversive productions.

Petr Forman graduated from Prague's puppet school in 1987, and Matej studied as an animation illustrator at the academy of fine arts. They started out as film actors, using their father's name to promote their double act. But after their first puppet show, for which they built a portable barn, they became popular in their own right.

Born in 1964, the twins were the product of Milos Forman's second marriage, to Vera Kresadlova. Four years later, their father left Czechoslovakia for the US. Now he is hovering proudly in the background. "He came to see the boat a month before the premiere," says Petr. "He was at the Berlin film festival catching the Golden Bear award for The Man on the Moon, and he rented a car to pop over the border, sleeping in our caravan on the river's edge." Since then he has telephoned every day.

Despite their father's financial and moral support, and the fact that Crimson Sails is playing to a packed boat every night, the money is running out. Each performance loses them around 65,000 crowns (£1,200), and the musicians have to be paid from the proceeds of the boat's bar. "We'll soon have to go begging to the ministry again," they say in unison. But then, pointing to a scale model of the Titanic on top of the bar, they manage a joke: "Although the boat is sinking, we're still dancing."

Australia knew in advance of the 1975 Indonesian invasion of East Timor and stood by for three days while Jakarta's troops prepared for the attack, secret documents released yesterday by the government revealed.

Memos, cables and letters sent and received by Australia's foreign department between 1974 and 1976 confirmed that Australia gave tacit approval to Jakarta to annex the former Portuguese colony.

East Timor voted overwhelmingly for independence last year and is under temporary United Nations control after the referendum triggered a wave of violence by pro-Jakarta militias.

Australia's foreign affairs minister, Alexander Downer, said the release of the documents ahead of the usual 30-year wait would help to clear the air over what is considered one of the most controversial events in Australian history.

The papers show that Australia's embassy in Jakarta received full details from Indonesia of the timing of an attack on the Timorese town of Balibo in October 1975 - three days before it occurred.

Five Australian journalists were killed in the assault.

Mr Downer said that although the Labour government of Gough Whitlam had advance warning of the attack, there was no evidence that Australia could have prevented the journalists' deaths.

"The Department of Foreign Affairs had no information beforehand of any intentions to kill the journalists, although it did have prior knowledge of the planned invasion," he said.

"I'm not today, with 25 years of hindsight, going to pass judgment on the actions of Australian ministers and officials during this critical exercise, nor will I offer opinions about the conduct of other governments at the time."

Australia's two main political parties have come under fire for their actions at the time. Mr Whitlam's Labour party was in office when Indonesia's then president Suharto ordered the invasion, and Malcolm Fraser's Liberal/National coalition was in power by the time Indonesia annexed East Timor in 1976.

Cabinet minutes from the time will not be released until the 30-year waiting period is up, and Mr Downer said intelligence reports might never be released for reasons of national security.

Australia was the only western nation to recognise Indonesia's rule over East Timor.

Human rights groups said up to 200,000 people died during the invasion and subsequent fighting and famine in East Timor, sparked by Portugal's withdrawal in 1975.

Indonesia and its western allies reacted to the withdrawal with alarm, fearing that pro-communist East Timorese were taking over and that another communist stronghold would emerge in the region, months after the fall of Saigon to the communists.

President Suharto also had tacit US support for the invasion, which took place just after a visit by the then president, Gerald Ford.

With Vietnam fresh in mind, Australia told Jakarta it did not want to get involved in East Timor - a territory it had once called "an essay in the hopeless". Critics said this gave President Suharto a green light to invade.

"While preferring the integration of Portuguese Timor with Indonesia, the Whitlam government wished there to be a genuine act of self-determination in the territory," Mr Downer said.

"Fears that Indonesia might seek to obtain the territory otherwise than by these means led the Whitlam government to adopt a policy of studied detachment."
